Answer: The problem in your code is that you are not closing the PrintWriter `writeToFile` after writing the contents of the file to the file. This causes the server to get stuck when it tries to read the second file name. 

To fix this, you need to close the `writeToFile` PrintWriter after you have finished writing the contents of the file. You can do this by calling the `close()` method on `writeToFile`. 

Here is the corrected code:

```java
else {
    writeToFile.println(response);
    pr.println("Echo from server -> " + response);
    writeToFile.flush();
    pr.flush();
}
writeToFile.close(); // Close the PrintWriter after writing the contents of the file
```

This will ensure that the `writeToFile` PrintWriter is properly closed after writing the contents of the file, allowing the server to continue processing the second file name.

Please note that you should also handle the case where `writeToFile` is null, which can occur if the file name does not end with ".txt".

Also, make sure to handle any exceptions that might occur when closing the `writeToFile` PrintWriter. You can do this by wrapping the `close()` method call in a try-catch block.

```java
try {
    writeToFile.close();
} catch (Exception e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}
```

This will ensure that any exceptions that might occur when closing the `writeToFile` PrintWriter are properly handled.
